data.title: Review: Ghostbusters II
data.text:
Ross Niebergall

unread,

to

I cannot say that I was overly impressed by the first "Ghostbusters"

movie. It was amusing and entertaining up to the point when the giant

marshmallow man appeared, and then it just became too silly to be

entertaining anymore. Now after seeing "Ghostbusters II" I would have to

give it a similar criticism. Both writers of the film, Harold Ramis and

Dan Aykroyd, started their careers as writers with Second City, and Aykroyd

went on to write for Saturday Night Live, while Ramis wrote for SCTV.

While doing this both proved that they are very capable of writing episodes

and skits. What appears to be lacking is their ability to come up with a

plot that remains reasonable for two full hours. "Ghostbusters II" has some

very funny scenes, but it seems as though they treat the climax of the film

as though if were just another scene with a bigger gag, and more special

effect than the rest.

This is not to say that the film does not have any redeeming qualities.

It is well directed by Ivan Reitman ("Twins") and the opening scene with

Sigourney Weaver chasing a possessed baby carriage through New York's streets

is particularly well done. Bill Murray livens up the picture with his

presence, and it is with his character that Ramis and Aykroyd's writing

styles are particularly suited. Murray's character has little to do with the

plot, but he is the center of attention of every scene he is in, and

deservedly so. He is entertaining enough to diffuse the weak plot. Clearly

he uses his ability to improvise, and this is seen well in the scenes he

plays with Weaver's characters baby. Ramis and Akyroyd also perform their

acting jobs adequately, and the dialogue between the three stars is excellent.

Certainly Akyroyd is the best actor there is at speaking "techno-gibberish".

The only place where the film fails is in the lack of an encompassing

plot, and if one is willing to forgive this, the movie is

entertaining, if only to see Murray, Aykroyd, and Ramis.
